H0.text: Which now obsolete unit originated as the distance a person could walk in an hour. Mile

H1.text: Which now obsolete unit originated as the distance a person could walk in an hour. League

H2.text: Which now obsolete unit originated as the distance a person could walk in an hour. Furlong

H3.text: Which now obsolete unit originated as the distance a person could walk in an hour. Legua

A4.text: It may have originally represented, roughly, the distance a person could walk in an hour.

A5.text: In some rural parts of Mexico, the league (Spanish legua) is still used in the original sense of the distance that can be covered on foot in an hour, so that a league along a good road on level ground is a greater distance than a league on a difficult path over rough terrain.

A6.text: The Dutch kleine mile had the historical definition of one hour's walking (uur gaans)

A7.text: The common Dutch mile was preferred by mariners, equating with 15 to one degree of latitude or one degree of longitude on the equator

A8.text: A league was considered to be the distance a man could walk in one hour

A9.text: The mile (from mille, meaning 'thousand') consisted of 1,000 passus (paces, five feet, or double-step)
